text: Google cardboard at first some delegates
here thought it was a joke but this
lowest of low tech contraptions unravels
to reveal startling high-tech
credentials magically transforming into
a pair of 3d virtual reality specs when
you slip a smartphone into the front
using orientation sensors in your
handset the scene changes when you move
it around the two side-by-side pictures
combined into a singular 3d image when
you look through the lenses in the
cardboard itself the effect is quite
mesmerizing and truly immersive when you
fire up one of the experiences google
has made one moment I'm taking a
breathtaking tour over Chicago by simply
gazing where I want to fly if I look up
I'm transported to space and find myself
looking down on Mother Earth then I
embark on my next virtual reality voyage
this time to the Palais de Versailles in
France the images are surprisingly sharp
though if I move around too quickly
I do feel a bit dizzy but overall it's
pretty impressive I think it's really
cool device it's a very simple concept I
think it's very like like the viewer a
stick feeding this is pretty good they
had a pretty clever idea doing that at
home I would use it just for fun not
maybe for heavy usage you feel a bit
like uncomfortable after a few a few
minutes but no it's pretty calm and they
have some very good use cases here using
a handset for VR isn't entirely new but
cost aside are the clever little touches
make this card wear stand out like NFC
tags which automatically launch the app
on a compatible phone and the side
magnet that triggers the phone's compass
to select various experiences
important thing to understand about our
project is we want to have it simple and
we want to have we want to give it out
to the developers including the open
source software for free to basically
spawn development and we think with this
is great for the field in general
already the concept born just six months
ago is generating huge buzz some are now
calling it the oculus rift it may lack
the refinement or elegance of its
pricier counterparts but who knows
cardboard could yet become bigger than
anyone expected
you
